nodes.bodyText: I would change the order to "RING".equals(callType) to avoid NPEs later on
callType is NonNull, so there is no risk.

True for the moment, until someone will change something in the future ;-) and doesn't look on the lines below line 48. For example format changes on the raw line by AVM or something similiar. From aspects of change-proof code I would prefer if you turn around those statements. But this is still my personal suggestion!
I think 5 seconds is really long reaction time for binding, Maybe this should be a configuration Parameter
I changed it to 1 second. Don't think there's any need to make it configurable.

If I remind correctly call monitor is not activated by default on the fritz box. So maybe this should be although configurable whether call monitor should be initiated. We could reuse the config parameter above.
I now only instantiate the CallMonitor connection, if one of the related channels is linked.
See my comment above about activation of call monitor. So this channels should be added dynamicly if call monitor is active

nodes.bodyText: Don't we have to UNDEF the other channels all the time? Otherwise their state will remain on old value until the next call / event.
good point.
Sry to be nit-picking on this. According our guidelines we should set the state to UnDefType.UNDEF.

Which guideline is that? UNDEF is to be used in case the state cannot be mapped to any sensible value and NULL, if no state exists at all (yes, this might be debatable here, but it seems both values can be found arguments for). But if you prefer UNDEF, I can change it.
Hm, ... I always thought the state should only be NULL after restart of OH and otherwise one always should use UNDEF if there is no valid data available to set.

In most cases that is the case this way. But there are a few exceptional cases, where it is better to say that a channel simply does not have ANY state and then NULL is the better match. E.g. when a device operates in a mode, where the channel does not make any functional sense (yeah, ideally, the channel should then be dynamically completely removed).
But yeah, I am thus fine with UNDEF here for the call channels. In 1.x, the CallType had a dedicated EMPTY value, but this does not exist for us anymore.
This should have org.eclipse.smarthome.core.thing namespace.
Oops. It can actually be removed as it isn't used at all. No idea why it was there...
Should we dispose the CallMonitor if all call monitor channels are unlinked?
done.
You can reuse the callChannelsLinked() method here. Maybe store its result in local variable and access it later.
Indeed, I had moved that method from another class and forgot to make use of it here. As there are only 5 channels on this bridge, I don't cache the result as I don't think it has a big impact.
I do not understand this? Why do you need to override it and just call the super method?
Because we make the method public (while being protected in the super class), so that the CallMonitor thread can access it on the handler object.
This method stops the whole polling job for updating all devices. We should not do that.
Oh, you're right, thanks for noticing!
see above
I'm not sure, whether for users help we should although document how to deactivate again?

 # AVM FRITZ! Binding
 
-The binding integrates the AHA ( [AVM Home Automation](https://avm.de/ratgeber/smart-home/) ) system.  
+The binding integrates AVM FRITZ!Boxes with a special focus on the AHA ( [AVM Home Automation](https://avm.de/ratgeber/smart-home/) ) features.  
 
 ## Supported Things
 
 ### FRITZ!Box
 
-The well known FRITZ!Boxes are supported as bridge for accessing other AHA devices.
-It is planned to support some channels directly at the bridge like call monitoring and others - but these things are under current development by now.
-The Box has to run at least on firmware FRITZ!OS 6.00 and has to support the "Smart Home" service.
+FRITZ!Boxes (thing type `fritzbox`) are supported as bridges and they offer channels for call monitoring.
+To activate the call monitor interface on a FRITZ!Box, you need to dial once `#96*5*` on a connected telephone.
